triplet_3134_question.question: What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_3134_question.text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession?
triplet_3134_question.displayed_text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession?

triplet_3134_rating.question: What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_3134_rating.text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Here are the comments you provided:

It's not for me, but I appreciate the medium for those who enjoy it. I know people earn livings this way and I support them fully.

i have a positive opinion on them, it looks like it opens many doors for them and I also enjoy watching their content and their product's recommendations. some of them have really good content.

I don't personally relate or identify with this specific job/career choice but I understand why it is becoming widespread. It seems fitting given the proliferation of social media in the last decade or so.

They are doing something they like to do and have the convenience of doing it online at their own convenience. Many are fortunate to make very good income.

I think it makes sense that being an internet influencer is now seen as a real profession, since so many people rely on them for ideas, advice, and entertainment. They play a big role in shaping trends and connecting with audiences in a way traditional jobs don’t. At the same time, I feel it’s important for the space to stay authentic and responsible.

I find influencers to be annoying. They do not seem to be genuine and I find it silly that people are foolish enough to be affected by them.

Influencers are a great addition to the internet. Not only are they entertaining they have been informative about information that has not broadcast on the news. With this being said I believe this will be the new wave of how we actually get news in the truth.

It’s almost like celebrities in the 90s, there’s really no difference except influencers may be more down to earth and expose more of their personal life at first.

They entertain, pass knowledge and information to the masses, they're the new media houses. While it might seem new to a lot of people, a number of streamers give insightful and cited information. As well as entertain.

I think it’s very fun and sort of an easy way to get income all while just living your life. Of course having to keep up with trends after a while people tend to just start following one another. Everyone ends up having/wearing the same thing, no one likes to be creative anymore or unique.

Overall Summary

Overall, there is a general acknowledgment of internet influencing as a legitimate and widespread profession, though perspectives on its value and impact are mixed.

A significant portion of comments express a positive or supportive view. Influencing is seen as a valid career that allows individuals to earn a good income doing something they enjoy with flexibility. For the audience, influencers are valued as sources of entertainment, product recommendations, advice, and information. Some commentators view them as a modern evolution of celebrity or even as "new media houses" that can provide insightful, cited information and potentially serve as a future source for news.

Conversely, there is also clear skepticism and criticism. Some find influencers to be annoying, lacking in genuineness, and silly. Concerns were raised about their societal impact, suggesting they can stifle creativity and promote conformity by encouraging mass trend-following.

A neutral viewpoint also emerged, where even those who do not personally relate to the profession understand its rise as a logical consequence of social media's growth. Across the different perspectives, there is a recurring acknowledgment of the significant role influencers play in shaping trends, alongside a call for them to maintain authenticity and responsibility.

triplet_3134_comparison.question: What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_3134_comparison.text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Here are the comments you provided:

It's not for me, but I appreciate the medium for those who enjoy it. I know people earn livings this way and I support them fully.

i have a positive opinion on them, it looks like it opens many doors for them and I also enjoy watching their content and their product's recommendations. some of them have really good content.

I don't personally relate or identify with this specific job/career choice but I understand why it is becoming widespread. It seems fitting given the proliferation of social media in the last decade or so.

They are doing something they like to do and have the convenience of doing it online at their own convenience. Many are fortunate to make very good income.

I think it makes sense that being an internet influencer is now seen as a real profession, since so many people rely on them for ideas, advice, and entertainment. They play a big role in shaping trends and connecting with audiences in a way traditional jobs don’t. At the same time, I feel it’s important for the space to stay authentic and responsible.

I find influencers to be annoying. They do not seem to be genuine and I find it silly that people are foolish enough to be affected by them.

Influencers are a great addition to the internet. Not only are they entertaining they have been informative about information that has not broadcast on the news. With this being said I believe this will be the new wave of how we actually get news in the truth.

It’s almost like celebrities in the 90s, there’s really no difference except influencers may be more down to earth and expose more of their personal life at first.

They entertain, pass knowledge and information to the masses, they're the new media houses. While it might seem new to a lot of people, a number of streamers give insightful and cited information. As well as entertain.

I think it’s very fun and sort of an easy way to get income all while just living your life. Of course having to keep up with trends after a while people tend to just start following one another. Everyone ends up having/wearing the same thing, no one likes to be creative anymore or unique.

Overall Summary

Overall, there is a general acknowledgment of internet influencing as a legitimate and widespread profession, though perspectives on its value and impact are mixed.

A significant portion of comments express a positive or supportive view. Influencing is seen as a valid career that allows individuals to earn a good income doing something they enjoy with flexibility. For the audience, influencers are valued as sources of entertainment, product recommendations, advice, and information. Some commentators view them as a modern evolution of celebrity or even as "new media houses" that can provide insightful, cited information and potentially serve as a future source for news.

Conversely, there is also clear skepticism and criticism. Some find influencers to be annoying, lacking in genuineness, and silly. Concerns were raised about their societal impact, suggesting they can stifle creativity and promote conformity by encouraging mass trend-following.

A neutral viewpoint also emerged, where even those who do not personally relate to the profession understand its rise as a logical consequence of social media's growth. Across the different perspectives, there is a recurring acknowledgment of the significant role influencers play in shaping trends, alongside a call for them to maintain authenticity and responsibility.

Summary B

Overall, sentiment leans supportive of internet influencing as a legitimate profession, with about 70% expressing positive or cautiously positive views, roughly 20% skeptical or negative, and the remainder neutral or mixed.

Key reasons for support - Seen as a natural evolution of media and commerce, comparable to entertainment or celebrity culture but more accessible and relatable. - Offers creators flexibility, income opportunities, and a platform to share expertise, entertain, and build communities. - Perceived as a useful source of information and, in some cases, a supplement or alternative to traditional news. - Celebrated for democratizing who gets a voice and enabling everyday people to reach niche audiences.

Concerns and criticisms - Oversaturation and homogenization: too many creators chasing trends, reducing originality. - Authenticity and “fakeness,” with worries about performative behavior and misleading influence. - Incentives that may encourage sensationalism or risky behavior to gain views. - Potential societal downsides: unrealistic ideas about success, internet addiction, and a fragmented public discourse (e.g., “Tower of Babel” analogies). - Quality control and misinformation risks, especially when creators function like news sources.

Expectations and conditions for legitimacy - Clear accountability, ethical conduct, and transparency (e.g., sponsorship disclosures). - Responsibility toward audiences, especially younger viewers. - Recognition that success requires real work and skills; it is not “easy money.” - Consideration of reasonable regulation or industry standards.

Context and trends - Rapid growth noted during the COVID era. - Shifting consumer trust from traditional advertising to personalized recommendations. - Viability often hinges on discoverability and initial publicity.

Bottom line: Most commenters view influencing as a valid, modern profession with real benefits, provided creators act responsibly and authentically. Skeptics highlight oversaturation, inauthenticity, and social harms, suggesting the field’s long-term credibility depends on accountability, quality, and media literacy.

triplet_3134_comparison.summary_b_text:
Overall, sentiment leans supportive of internet influencing as a legitimate profession, with about 70% expressing positive or cautiously positive views, roughly 20% skeptical or negative, and the remainder neutral or mixed.

Key reasons for support
- Seen as a natural evolution of media and commerce, comparable to entertainment or celebrity culture but more accessible and relatable.
- Offers creators flexibility, income opportunities, and a platform to share expertise, entertain, and build communities.
- Perceived as a useful source of information and, in some cases, a supplement or alternative to traditional news.
- Celebrated for democratizing who gets a voice and enabling everyday people to reach niche audiences.

Concerns and criticisms
- Oversaturation and homogenization: too many creators chasing trends, reducing originality.
- Authenticity and “fakeness,” with worries about performative behavior and misleading influence.
- Incentives that may encourage sensationalism or risky behavior to gain views.
- Potential societal downsides: unrealistic ideas about success, internet addiction, and a fragmented public discourse (e.g., “Tower of Babel” analogies).
- Quality control and misinformation risks, especially when creators function like news sources.

Expectations and conditions for legitimacy
- Clear accountability, ethical conduct, and transparency (e.g., sponsorship disclosures).
- Responsibility toward audiences, especially younger viewers.
- Recognition that success requires real work and skills; it is not “easy money.”
- Consideration of reasonable regulation or industry standards.

Context and trends
- Rapid growth noted during the COVID era.
- Shifting consumer trust from traditional advertising to personalized recommendations.
- Viability often hinges on discoverability and initial publicity.

Bottom line: Most commenters view influencing as a valid, modern profession with real benefits, provided creators act responsibly and authentically. Skeptics highlight oversaturation, inauthenticity, and social harms, suggesting the field’s long-term credibility depends on accountability, quality, and media literacy.
